body_text.text: . What is even less clear is to what extent the 27 postponement of uro-oncological procedures will impact 28 patients and health care systems, given that the duration of 29 the crisis is unpredictable and likely prolonged [5] .

To provide a snapshot of the current uro-oncological 31 management in Europe during the COVID-19 emergency 32 and to estimate its future consequences, we conducted a 33 survey involving 57 European urological referral centers.

Urologists were asked to report on their activity concerning across Europe: radical prostatectomies, radical cystec-52 tomies, radical/partial nephrectomies, and nephroureter-53 ectomies decreased by 53%, 41%, 53%, and 52%, respectively.

The majority of radical prostatectomies nowadays are 55 performed with the robotic technique at referral centers, 56 but the restrictions have specifically affected the access to 57 the robot [4] . Centers estimate that >50% of uro-oncological 58 procedures will have a delay well beyond 30 d from 59 diagnosis, which is the recommended time frame within 60 which newly diagnosed cases should definitely be treated 61 [5] .

This is of special concern as the delay in a timely 63 treatment will jeopardize oncological outcomes and have a 64 ripple effect on future patients who will also suffer due to press. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41585-020-0312-1.

BIBREF5.title: Urology in the time of corona

FIGREF0.text: COVID-19) has been declared a pandemic by the World 10 Health Organization on March 11, 2020 [1]. This outbreak hit 11 Europe deeply, with 582 554 cases and 47 741 deaths having 12 been reported as of April 6, 2020 [2]. Despite the 13 containment efforts implemented by the national political 14 and health authorities of each Country, the pandemic has 15 not reached its peak yet. 16 The exponential increase in the number of cases 17 translated into an urgent need to reallocate medical 18 resources to the assistance of COVID-19 patients, with 19 redistribution of medical/surgical activities not primarily 20 involved in the management of COVID-19 patients [3]. In the 21 last month, in many European centers, the urological 22 activity has been limited to urgent procedures and 23 oncological priorities. However, what is to be considered 24 a uro-oncological priority remains debatable, despite some 25 recommendations having recently been published 26

FIGREF2.text: Our results showed that the management of the main 39 urological cancers has been altered dramatically by COVID-40 19 pandemic, with most European centers (82%) declaring 41 to be "much" or "very much" affected. Uro-oncological 42 consultations for newly diagnosed cancers and follow-up 43 were more than halved or almost suspended, in 55% and 71% 44 of centers, respectively. Prostate biopsies were reduced by 45 62%, with an average decrease of 23 biopsies per month. 46 Given the aggressive nature of urothelial cancers, the 47 restriction for transurethral resections of bladder tumors 48 was smaller but still significant (46%), with a mean decrease 49 of 12 procedures per month. In March 2020, a dramatic 50 reduction was seen in major uro-oncological surgeries 51

FIGREF3.text: 65 lengthening of waiting lists. After the end of the COVID-19 66 crisis, health systems will have to develop strategies to 67 catch up with these delays. Given similar reduction rates 68 from normal activity to what was seen in March, we tried to 69 estimate the medical working capacity, which would be 70 needed in order to absorb uro-oncological interventions 71 that have been postponed second to the pandemic. The 72 result has been derived from random simulation of monthly 73 reductions in each type of intervention, as well in their total, 74 based on the statistical distribution of survey reduction 75 rates. 76 We found that, in the near future, uro-oncological 77 surgeries should dramatically increase to treat all patients 78 accumulated on waiting lists (Fig. 1). From patients' point of 79 view, the waiting time for uro-oncological procedures in 80 Europe is estimated to double by the end of April and triple this article in press as: Oderda M, et al. The Impact of COVID-19 Outbreak on Uro-oncological Practice Across Europe: Which Burden of Activity Are We Facing Ahead? Eur Urol (2020), https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eururo.2020.04.036 https://doi.org/10.1016/j.eururo.2020.04.036 0302-2838/© 2020 Published by Elsevier B.V. on behalf of European Association of Urology. 81 by the end of June. As surgical volumes of each institution 82 cannot increase beyond a certain point, this will be a 83 challenging but important issue to be addressed, specifi-84 cally as the access to resources will be phased and 85 competitive. In the meantime, delays in the waiting list 86 might also have important implications in terms of patient 87 anxiety and related depression.

FIGREF4.text: Our work may not provide precise estimates, as there are 89 slight differences between European regions in terms of the 90 pandemic's course and effects. Different health care system 91 resources, sociocultural backgrounds, and restrictive gov-92 ernmental measures also act as confounders. However, we 93 provide a first timely estimate of the indirect effect of 94 COVID-19 pandemic on the uro-oncological care based on 95 real-time, first-hand reports of urological case patterns in 96 Europe. In the time of crisis, uro-oncological surgeries 97 should be centralized in tertiary urological centers that 98 should ideally remain COVID-19-free sanctuaries, to 99 guarantee high-quality, timely, and safe treatments to 100 oncological patients. The health care fallout of the COVID-19 101 pandemic will surely be measured by the direct morbidity/ 102 mortality of the virus as well as the secondary effect that 103 will include significant harm from delay of urgent 104 oncological therapies, including surgeries. 105 Conflicts of interest: The authors have nothing to disclose. 106 Acknowledgments: We are thankful to all centers that participated in the 107 Covid-19 European Uro-Oncology (CoEUrO) group survey,
